author: Bong Eats
title: Lau Chingri
ingredients: 100 g kucho chingri (tiny freshwater prawns, cleaned and deveined with head on)
instructions:
Clean and devein the prawns. Smear them with ¼ tsp each of salt and turmeric. Set aside.
Peel the lau, and chop it in 5-mm thick strips, 4 cm long.
Place an empty kadai on the stove. Once it has heated up fully, add mustard oil. Wait for it to give off a gentle smoke and turn pale yellow.
Fry the marinated prawns in it for 30 seconds. Don’t overfry, or they will become tough. Remove from the oil and set aside.
Temper the same (now-prawn-flavoured) oil with a dried red chilli, bay leaf, cinnamon, cardamom, cloves and cumin seeds.
Add cumin powder and turmeric. Fry these on low heat for 2 minutes before adding the ginger paste. Fry for another 2 minutes. If the spices start sticking to the pan, you may add splashes of water and continue frying.
Add lau, green chillies and salt. Mix everything and cover the pan with a lid.
You will now have to cook this, stirring occasionally, until the spices are well braised and the lau has ‘reduced’. This can take anything from 25–40 minutes.
Add sugar and continue cooking until the liquid has more or less dried up.
Add the fried prawns and continue braising until a very light caramelisation stage is reached.
Finish with ghee, Bengali garam masala and chopped coriander leaves.
